channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: United Arab Emirates Want to Top the World in Happiness, Too
item.description: The emirates already have the world’s tallest building and a wealth of international talent. Soon, they will also have ministers of happiness and tolerance.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum, at center, the prime minister of the United Arab Emirates and ruler of Dubai in 2015. He announced the new ministries on Twitter.

item.title: British Effort to Identify Potential Radicals Spurs Debate Over Profiling
item.description: A program encouraging fellow citizens to identify potential radicals has also raised questions about racial and religious profiling and the balance between security and civil liberties.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A street in Bethnal Green, East London, home to a conservative Muslim community. Four teenage girls from a school in the area were drawn to the Islamic State.

item.title: German Train Crash Leaves 10 Dead and Scores Injured
item.description: Two commuter trains collided head-on in the southeastern state of Bavaria, an accident that the police said was among the worst in the region.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:credit: Peter Kneffel/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Two commuter trains collided head-on near Bad Aibling, southeast of Munich, on Tuesday.

item.title: Seeking Only Bodies on Indian Glacier, Soldiers Find Survivor
item.description: The 10 solders buried under a wall of ice on Siachen Glacier were assumed dead. But Indians celebrated as one was found clinging to life.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and HARI KUMAR
item.media:credit: Indian Defence Ministry, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Indian Army soldiers searching for survivors on Monday after a deadly avalanche on the Siachen Glacier.

item.title: U.S. to Send More Troops to Aid Afghan Forces Pressed by Taliban
item.description: The deployment will be the Americans’ largest outside a major base in Afghanistan since 2014 and will support beleaguered troops in Helmand Province.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: American Marines in Kandahar, Afghanistan, in 2014 after withdrawing from a military complex in Helmand Province, where Afghan forces are now being pressed by the Taliban.

item.title: ‘Basil,’ Fugitive in England’s Biggest Heist, May Be Ex-Policeman
item.description: In a letter, a ringleader of the $20 million Hatton Garden Safe Deposit burglary calls “Basil,” who has vanished, “the brains” of the 2015 operation.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The entrance to the Hatton Garden Safe Deposit bank, the site of the largest burglary in England’s history.

item.title: Palace of Henry VIII to Hold First Catholic Service in Nearly 500 Years
item.description: Hampton Court Palace will host vespers in a symbol of the growing reconciliation between the Roman Catholic Church and the Church of England.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:credit: Andy Haslam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hampton Court Palace, near London. In 1530, King Henry VIII sent the first letter threatening to break off ties with the Catholic Church in Rome from the palace.

item.title: Neighbors Had Doubts About Complex That Collapsed in Taiwan Quake
item.description: People living near Tainan’s Wei-Guan Golden Dragon complex say that locals avoided buying condominiums there and that its 17 stories far exceed what would be allowed today.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: The 17-story Wei-Guan Golden Dragon apartment complex on Monday, two days after it collapsed in an earthquake in Tainan, southern Taiwan.

item.title: ISIS, in a First, Says It’s Behind Attack in Capital of Syria
item.description: A car bomb tore up a vegetable market and a police officers’ club in the capital of Syria, striking an area that had been quiet for about two years.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: A car bombing struck an area of Damascus that had been quiet for about two years under a local agreement between the Syrian government and insurgents.

item.title: Tampere Journal: A Three-Ring Circus in Finland: Soldiers, ‘Loldiers’ and Asylum Seekers
item.description: About 1,200 refugees so far have relocated to Finland’s third-largest city, prompting a rise in nationalists, and in champions of multiculturalism.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: RICHARD MARTYN-HEMPHILL
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Loldiers of Odin last month in Tampere, Finland. The troupe of clowns is dedicated to mocking the Soldiers of Odin and other nationalists in the country.

item.title: Taiwan Earthquake Investigators Arrest Developer of Collapsed Building
item.description: Lin Minghui and two associates were being held on suspicion of bearing some responsibility for the structure’s collapse, an official said.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: A worker early on Tuesday searching through the debris of an apartment complex that collapsed during the earthquake.

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: Yan Xuetong Urges China to Adopt a More Assertive Foreign Policy
item.description: In a new book, Yan Xuetong of Tsinghua University calls on China to forge military partnerships abroad and build a more humane society at home.
item.dc:creator: YUFAN HUANG
item.media:description: The People’s Liberation Army at the military parade to honor the 70th anniversary of the end of World War II in Beijing in September.

item.title: Rocket Suggests North Korea Made Small Gains in Technology, South Says
item.description: The rocket that North Korea launched this week had a longer range than the one used to put a satellite in orbit in 2012, South Korean officials said.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: A North Korean man in the town of Sinuiju as seen from across the Yalu River in the border city of Dandong, China.

item.title: Reporter’s Notebook: Traveling Through Venezuela, a Country Teetering on the Brink
item.description: Our reporter explores the country and its people in his first 30 days in the region on assignment for The Times.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: The changing of the guard in Caracas at the tomb of President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela, who died in 2013.

item.title: Britain’s Global Banking Hub Is Mostly Leery of an E.U. Exit
item.description: London is a center of international trading, and most banking executives say that they would have much to lose from a so-called Brexit. But some see benefits.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:credit: Andy Haslam for The New York Times
item.media:description: London is a major financial gateway, the biggest and busiest in Europe and rivaling Wall Street as a hub of international trading in stocks, bonds, currencies and commodities.

item.title: Protesters and Police Clash at Lunar New Year Festivities in Hong Kong
item.description: Nearly 50 police officers were reported injured and 54 protesters were arrested after officers attempted to shut down unlicensed food vendors.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Turban-Wearing Sikh American Actor Is Barred From Aeroméxico
item.description: Waris Ahluwalia, who follows the Sikh religion, was not allowed to board a flight in Mexico City bound for New York unless, he said, he took off his turban for a security check.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER
item.media:description: Waris Ahluwalia said Aeroméxico prevented him from boarding a flight to New York because he refused to remove his turban affiliated with his Sikh faith.

item.title: Egypt Official Rejects Any Role of Security Forces in Italian’s Killing
item.description: The interior minister denied that Giulio Regeni, whose brutalized body was found near Cairo last week, had been in police custody before his murder.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM and NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: Russian Companies Rush to Return to Post-Sanctions Iran
item.description: Russia has an advantage in pursuing trade with Iran because it has long backed the country diplomatically and it has strong military ties.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the Volzhsky Pipe Plant’s administrative office, an exibit of artwork titled “Tube or Not Tube?” with scenes showing pipes, or “tubes”, from the plant’s manufacturing floors blended with works of art.

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: Trudeau Pulls Combat Jets From Syria, but Keeps Other Aircraft
item.description: An aerial refueling tanker and two long-range surveillance aircraft will remain part of the military mission.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
